title: Add process.binding support
body:
ATM, I'm porting the fs module to the browser. There are 3 key obstacles that need to be overcome to accomplish this:
1. Add process.binding support and an equivalent system to the /builtins directory for creating these.
2. Add process.binding('buffer') support, specifically SlowBuffer and TypedArray support.
3. Add process.binding('fs') support
   3*. Add process.binding('constants') support, at least for the referenced constants in fs.js

My purpose for posting this issue is to start the conversation about the best ways to achieve this. It seems like the simples would be to either have a convention in builtins where bindings are called something like fs.src.js (a reference to C++ file locations within the node source) or a folder within builtins, /builtins/src/:

process.binding('fs') => /builtins/src/fs.js

In the meantime I'm porting the process.binding shims inline within fs.js and buffer.js respectively.

title: Windows support - Revision to #137 and #126
body:
This is a revision of issues #137 and #126. I tested it on Windows and Mac OS X. Pull request #137 breaks Browserify for *nix because it replaces some of the *nix regexes with Windows-specific ones (e.g. instead of searching for a forward slash it searches for a backslash).

This new pull request removes most of the changes that seem unnecessary in #137. It changes only two areas of the lib/wrap.js code:
1.  For caching, it follows #137 by using process.env.USERPROFILE when process.env.HOME is not available. I verified that this creates a ".config/browserify/cache.json" file in my Windows home directory.
2.  Backslashes are replaced by forward slashes in the makeTarget function. This is done at the beginning of the function so that most of the regexes to not need to be changed. Wherever path.normalize() is used, backslashes are again replaced with forward slashes.

Interested parties please test this code, especially because I removed quite a few of the previously proposed modifications in #137. I tested it on a project of moderate complexity.

title: fix relative file target to use deepest node_modules directory
body:
In the case of nested node_modules where the file root is not just a prefix of the other path, browserify will calculate the wrong relative path for the module target. It properly includes the module source but then cannot find the module in the browser.

For example:

arguments to /lib/wrap.js/makeTarget:
file: `/projects/marketing/node_modules/derby-examples/node_modules/derby/lib/derby.browser.js`
root: `/projects/marketing/node_modules/derby-examples/chat/lib/chat`
returns: `/node_modules/derby-examples/node_modules/derby/lib/derby.browser.js`

when it should return
 `/node_modules/derby/lib/derby.browser.js`

Instead of starting the target path after the first node_modules directory, using the deepest node_modules directory fixes the issue.

title: Browserify + Windows = Client-side error
body:
http://jsfiddle.net/cjblomqvist/ZGfTQ/

Basically, I've found the problem to have to do with windows using backslashes (), whereas *nix and browsers/http uses forward slashes (/) and browserify doesn't seem to be able to handle this properly. I've come to the following conclusions:

To be able to have consistent code across platforms, one would prefer to keep the require('./your-file') syntax, so basically this means that in the generated file, the double backslashes (one extra for escaping) that gets put in the require.define call's first argument/parameter needs to be re-written to *nix -style (forward slashes).

title: How to use jquery-browserify and other *-browserify libs
body:
Hello,

I am completely lost on how to use jquery-browserify, and what is the actual goal for it.

In my node.js application I use (and `require 'jquery'`), and it works fine when running my application in node.

We're building a chrome application... which means that we're not serving this web app from a node.js server or a web server as a matter of facts. We wrote everything using node so that we have a better reutilization of our code between the various views of our application, but also a very simple way to test the application from the command line, rather than from the browser.

Now, when compiling my application using browserify, I get the following error:

```
node.js:201
        throw e; // process.nextTick error, or 'error' event on first tick
              ^
Error: Cannot find module "location" from directory "/Users/julien/repos/msgboy/node_modules/jquery"
    at Function.<anonymous> (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/browserify/lib/wrap.js:363:19)
    at Function.require (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/browserify/index.js:159:28)
    at /usr/local/lib/node_modules/browserify/lib/wrap.js:441:14
    at Array.forEach (native)
    at Function.<anonymous> (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/browserify/lib/wrap.js:440:27)
    at Function.require (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/browserify/index.js:159:28)
    at /usr/local/lib/node_modules/browserify/lib/wrap.js:441:14
    at Array.forEach (native)
    at Function.<anonymous> (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/browserify/lib/wrap.js:440:27)
    at Function.require (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/browserify/index.js:159:28)
```

So, I assumed this was because I needed to use the jquery-browserify. 
I tried replacing all the `require('jquery')` with `require('jquery-browserify')`, but then I have issues because it seems that this module makes calls to `window` which obviously isn't defined in node.js.

So, I used `--alias 'jquery:jquery-browserify'` to compile my application. It does compile just fine, but then, I get an error in my browser: `Uncaught Error: Cannot find module 'jquery-browserify'`

So I'm a bit lost. What's the goal of jquery-browserify and how to use it?

title: Fixed several bugs in watch

Fixed mtime checks in watch. Was comparing Date objects. Should compare actual timestamps. This caused compiling to continue happening when nothing was being modified.

This is a legit commit! Thanks for being patient while I figure the code out.

title: Increase compile speed for most scripts.
body:
The biggest pain with browserify is the speed of compile during development. When changing a file one must wait for a compile to finish before refreshing the browser to test.

This is an attempt to address the speed of browserify as defined in issue 90: https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/90.

The bottle-neck is the AST conversion and walking to pull out require statements. Using a simple regular expression to find all require statements drastically improves the speed for regular (non-uglified) compiles. This will make development using browserify much less painful.

The regular expression may need a little tweaking to ensure it matches appropriately against all cases, however this is a good place to start from. Any ideas for making this better are welcome. Any pointers on why this is not a viable solution are also welcome.

title: Fix loading toplevel directory from subdir in prelude
body:
Consider the following package structure: - package.json: 
{   "name":"testpkg",
  "main":"./index.js",
  "browserify":"./browser.js"
  }
- index.js: 
exports.stuff = 'for node';
- browser.js: 
exports.stuff = 'for browser';
  window.onload = function() {
  alert('code loaded, it works!');
  }
- entry.js: 
require('./subdir/require-super');
- subdir/require-super.js: 
require('../');
When running the browsified version of entry.js in a browser, the following error is thrown: 
Uncaught Error: Cannot find module '../'
The loadAsDirectory function of the prelude script prepended to browserified modules strips off trailing slashes before concatenating the argument with '/package.js' and '/index'. If the argument is a single slash, i.e. a path pointing to the root directory, it should be preserved when passing to path.resolve subsequently. Fix this problem by stripping off trailing slashes only for package/index lookup.

title: Browserify creates subfolder named 'undefined' in project folder
body:
When running node.js via monit script (which is not a rare situation), `process.env.HOME` is undefined. By default, the [file path of the cache.json is constructed relative to that directory](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/lib/wrap.js#L22), which is then given to deputy, which does mkdirp.

Solution would be f.ex. to check if `process.env.HOME` exists and if not, default to placing cache.json in project folder.

Current workaround: set `cache: false`

Browserify: v1.8.0
Nodejs: v0.6.1

title: Possible memory leak error message
body:
Using Browserify 1.8.0 and node 0.6.1 I'm getting the following messsage logged to the console.

(node) warning: possible EventEmitter memory leak detected. 11 listeners added. Use emitter.setMaxListeners() to increase limit.
18 Nov 10:43:51 - [ERROR] Trace
Trace: 
    at StatWatcher.<anonymous> (events.js:133:17)
    at Object.watchFile (fs.js:731:8)
    at Array.0 (/Users/itaylor/menu/node_modules/browserify/index.js:102:24)
    at EventEmitter._tickCallback (node.js:192:40)

After rolling back to 1.7.4 I don't get the error anymore

title: browserify very slow at startup with node 0.6.0
body:
Browserify got really slow at startup with node 0.6.0 on OS X.  I can't figure out why, and I've run out of time to work on this, so here's a braindump in case somebody else is trying  to figure this out.

Details: node 0.6.0, browserify 1.7.6, dnode 0.9.2, OS X 10.7.2

Relevant code in server:

``` javascript
  var start = Date.now();
  var b = require('browserify')({ require : ['dnode'] });
  debug('browserify took: ' + (Date.now() - start) + 'ms.');
```

With node 0.6.0, I get: "browserify took: 11907ms".  (Yes, 12 seconds!)  With node 0.4.11, I get: "browserify took: 2079ms".

I got a profile with "node --prof app.js" followed by "node-v0.6.0/deps/v8/tools/mac-tick-processor" - see blow for the interesting part.  My interpretation is that it's spending 37% of its time doing something (what?) in node, and 33% in _chmod, which is getting invoked from burrito somehow.  I'm totally baffled by the _chmod calls - as far as I can tell, no Javascript invokes it, and it's only called in the node source in a very few places.

title: Watch option doesn't works for entry file
body: I'm trying `browserify --watch -e entry.js -o bundle.js`. Where entry.js `require(./module.js)`. It's okay to edit module.js, bundle.js is regenerated. But edit entry.js itself doesn't causes regeneration. Maybe because module.js is in Wrap.files but entry.js doesn't?

title: Remove generated "base" require code from generated file - Create browserify.js
body:
I would like to break my files into chunks and when I run it through the browserify command it adds this to each file!
- https://gist.github.com/1329534

That type of thing should be placed into an external library.  If it's an external library, I get the following benefits:
1. A standard lib that can be minified, gzipped, and even cached on something like http://code.google.com/apis/libraries/.
2. A clean wrapper for each bundle, which would just look like:

``` javascript
require.define("aModule", function (require, module, exports, __dirname, __filename) {

});
require("aModule");
// maybe some others
```

instead of https://gist.github.com/1329534.

This way you'd have a cacheable HTML script tag like this:

``` html
<script src="/javascripts/browserify.js" type="text/javascript"></script>
<script src="/javascripts/aModule.js" type="text/javascript"></script>
<!-- … -->
```

I feel like this must be in here as a configuration option somewhere, maybe I've missed something.  Any suggestions?  Can this be added fairly easily if it doesn't already exist?  Something like a simple command line argument:

```
browserify --bare ./lib/aModule.js -o ./dist/aModule.js
```

I'm down to submit a patch if this makes sense.  Thanks for your help.

title: Object.keys shim is inadequate
body:
Hi there —

I noticed that the Object.keys shim used by browserify has an unfiltered for-in loop, meaning that it is not compatible with the standard method, which returns only the keys of the object's own properties.  I was going to fix it and offer a pull request, but then it occurred to me that the fix would require a shim for Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty, and so I decided to tell you guys about it instead, and maybe after some discussion we can fix it.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Object/keys

Regards,
Chris

title: Description of ignore() is wrong... and Browserify is slow
body:
The method ignore() doesn't quite do what it promises.
Current Description: Omit a file or files from being included by the AST walk to hunt down require() statements.
Actual Description: Omit a file entirely.

What about a method that does NOT walk the AST, but still wraps the file?  For example, I want to include jquery-browserify in my bundle, but there is no need to walk the AST for that entire source file because there are no require() statements in it.

My problem is that browserify takes FOREVER to walk the AST for these large libraries... all that CPU wasted.  Any thoughts on how we can fix this?

title: uglifier
Move wrapper.entry back to function() rather than process.nextTick
body:
Using `process.nextTick` as the entry wrapper introduces timing bugs. For example, if I have the following:

entry.js
`window.foobar = require('./mycode');`

clientside.js

`````` console.log(window.foobar.foo);```

index.html
``` <script type="text/javascript" src="browserified.js"></script> 
    <script type="text/javascript" src="clientside.js"></script>
``````

Sometimes, the above code will cause an exception because `window.foobar` is `undefined`, as the `entry.js` code has not yet been executed. Since no other code in the browserified source uses process.nextTick, it seems to make sense to execute the entry immediately (and I would claim that is the expectation with client-side JS at the moment).

title: Backbone is broken, created Browserify specific package
body:
https://github.com/kmiyashiro/backbone-browserify `npm install backbone-browserify`

Backbone is currently broken since it is wrapped in a closure and passed `this`. Browserify then wraps it in another closure and doesn't pass it anything, thus the Backbone closure's `this` is now `{}` instead of `window`. `window`  is used to grab window.jQuery or window.Zepto, which Backbone relies on.

title: Browserify supports caching (yep, "strong" and "weak")!
body:
Browserify now supports browser caching, both "strong" and "weak".

"Last-Modified" and "If-Modified-Since" are "weak" caching.  If the "If-Modified-Since" header is set, then Browserify can send 304 Not Modified, if appropriate, which saves bandwidth.

"Expires" or "Cache-Control: max-age" are "strong" caching.  The browser can simply pull from its own cache in certain cases to save an entire HTTP request.  In the client HTML, if the Browserify URL contains a query parameter that exactly matches the last modified date of the bundle, "strong" caching headers will be set.  This allows a user to easily implement URL fingerprinting by simply appending the last modified date of the Browserify bundle (b.modified) to the mount URL.  The full Browserify mount URL (including the needed query parameter) is made available via req.browserifyMount.  Finally, if Express is being utilitzed, the 'browserifyMount' local is available to views via res.locals(...).

Tested on Chrome 13 and IE 8, Node 0.4.11.
See http://code.google.com/speed/page-speed/docs/caching.html for more details.

title: Entry wrapper causes issues with reloads
body:
I found that the fact that browserify wraps the entry code in a process.nextTick call causes issues with reloads. For example:

I have a page where I do 'window.MyObject = require('MyObject');'
1. Load page the first time, everything works fine.
2. If I hit reload, it also works fine.
3. If I go to the URL bar and just press 'enter', everything breaks, because window.MyObject is not yet defined. 

If I add console.log to the generated browser-ified script, I can see that it has executed the process.nextTick call, but not the body of it yet. It does execute it eventually when the browser has finished loading some of the other JS files.

Is there any reason it is wrapped in process.nextTick rather than just (function(){ ...})()? If I make that change manually, it works great.

title: Fix relative requires when using watch
body: Browserify throws an exception when using relative requires that start with '../' with the watch option enabled, because require/makeTarget isn't aware of the root dir when reloading. This small patch passes the opts objects to Wrap.prototype.reload so it can pass opts.root to require/makeTarget.
